bibl.title: Letter from Carolyn H. Booth to Howard A. Kelly, December 10, 1907

div1.p: Booth notes the actions taken for Kissinger's pension and her attentions to the Kissinger family.

div1.head: Letter from Carolyn H. Booth to Howard A. Kelly, December 10, 1907
div1.opener:
L
not ans
138 So. Kenilworth Ave
Oak Park Ill.
Dec. 10-1907
Dear Dr Kelly:-
div1.p:
Until I received
the letter from your
Secy. of Dec. 6-1907, I did
not know that Mr Kissinger
had any pension at all.
hence my reason for
asking for all the
information I could
obtain regarding him.
Ac
Ki
My interest in his case
is very great, I admit, and
I have great hopes that
this appeal for a pension
of fifty-dollars for him
may be granted. Senator
Mason is not a Senator
from Ill. now, but an
Ex-Senator, but he felt
that his influence in
certain directions was
strong enough to assure
success. He is hoping for
a re-nomination- so he is in Touch
with all things political.

I regret that I have not known
more of the details regarding Mr
Kissinger, so I could properly
inform Mr Mason just how
the case stood -- but I handed
him all the papers I had con-
cerning the case on Dec 1st-
I shall send this last letter
from you (per secy) to him
at once, and thus I fear
I can do no more. but wait.
I have made Mr Kissinger
a member of our Shut-in
Society and my interest and
care of him will continue always.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours Carolyn H Booth
V.P. Winris Branch S.J.S. Mrs Henrey W. Broth.
